title: Testing
description: Requirements for product and environmental testing programs including microbiological testing, water quality testing, allergen testing, laboratory qualifications, and test result documentation

requirements.question: Is there a written risk-based, scientifically valid environmental monitoring program?

Are there written risk-based corrective action procedures for when unacceptable environmental monitoring test results are received, that describe the steps to be taken, and assign responsibility for taking those steps?
Are there records of environmental microbiological test results and does testing meet the program requirements?
Is there a written program describing the operation's requirements for other microbiological or chemical testing not identified in 5.16.01?

Are there written risk-based corrective action procedures for when unacceptable other microbiological or chemical test results are received, that describe the steps to be taken, and assign responsibility for taking those steps?
Are there records of microbiological tests on water used in the facility (sampled from within the facility) and does the testing meet the program requirements?
Are there records of microbiological tests on ice used in the facility (either produced in-house or purchased) and does testing meet the program requirements?
Are there records of tests performed on compressed air or other mechanically introduced gases that are used directly on food and food contact surfaces and does testing meet the program requirements?

Are there records of other tests (e.g., spent sprout irrigation water, product, raw ingredients, etc.) that are performed for any reason (e.g., customer requirements, best practice, regulatory requirements) and does testing meet program requirements?

Are there records of corrective actions taken after any unsuitable testing results that describe the steps taken, responsibility for taking those steps, and actions taken to ensure that the cause of contamination has been identified and corrected?
Is there a documented training program with training records for the sampling personnel, including aseptic sampling collection techniques, sampling protocols and sample handling?

Where food safety related testing is being done in-house, is there a laboratory quality assurance manual with protocols and validated testing methods, evidence of training on testing protocols and methods, and relevant supporting documentation?

capaInject: Implement immediate corrective actions when environmental monitoring detects pathogenic organisms including enhanced cleaning and retesting verification
Establish procedures for investigating root causes when microbiological test results exceed acceptable limits including environmental assessments
Develop action plans when water quality testing reveals coliforms or other indicators requiring system sanitization and source investigation
Create preventive measures for areas with persistent positive environmental monitoring results including equipment redesign or enhanced sanitation
Implement verification procedures to ensure testing laboratories maintain ISO 17025 accreditation and use validated testing methods
traceabilityInject: Maintain environmental monitoring program documentation including sampling locations, frequencies, target organisms, and scientifically validated rationale
Keep complete records of environmental microbiological test results with sampling dates, locations, organisms tested, and result interpretation
Retain corrective action records for unacceptable test results including investigation findings, remediation actions, and verification testing
Document water quality testing results including microbiological and chemical parameters, sampling points, and frequency compliance
Archive laboratory qualifications including ISO 17025 accreditation certificates, method validation reports, and proficiency testing results
micro_inject: Inadequate environmental monitoring fails to detect Listeria monocytogenes harborage sites allowing persistent contamination of ready-to-eat products
Water sources contaminated with E. coli or coliforms introduce pathogenic bacteria directly into product wash and cooling systems
Insufficient product testing frequency fails to identify pathogen contamination events including Salmonella outbreaks before distribution
Poor laboratory practices including contaminated media or improper sterile technique generate false negative results masking pathogen presence
Failure to test for indicator organisms misses early warning signs of sanitation failures that precede pathogenic contamination events
